name: Matalin Bloomfield
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
This graph displays the degree of human impact on the planet and how our choices can determine the fate of the climate.  It compares various food sources and their carbon dioxide output.  Greenhouse gases can be ozone-depleting and can force change in the climate.  The left side of the graph shows how many kilograms of carbon dioxide is being emitted as we eat protein-rich food items.  
The opposite side of the graph depicts food waste and which types of food create the most waste.  Food waste begins to rot and becomes a significant source of methane, another prevalent greenhouse gas pollutant.  The overarching effect of the graph is an awareness of how easily we can reduce our negative effects on the planet.

name: Lily Elbel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: This graph is depicting how much different foods people eat impact greenhouse gasses. Beef is the biggest 17.7kg of CO2 per 50 grams. That's pretty insane. The average hamburger is around 113 grams. That means for every hamburger there is approximately 35.4kg of CO2 emitted into the atmosphere.  Now on the other side of the picture we have a different graph showing how much people waste certain types of food. The most waste comes from seafood and fish. I would assume that’s because seafood spoils relatively fast. If people were willing to prepare a serving of fish (which is typically around 140 grams) you would be emitting around 9kg CO2. This means that one hamburger would emit the same amount of CO2 as almost FOUR servings of fish. Fish is clearly the better choice when it comes to greenhouse gasses.

name: Harrison Carter
comment info:
When I looked at the graph on the left I first noticed how damaging raising cattle is to the environment.  Getting 50 grams of protein from beef causes the release of 17.7 kilograms of Carbon Dioxide into the environment.  This is almost twice the Carbon Dioxide that is produced when the same amount of protein is extracted from lambs.  According to the graph, lamb and beef account for just under half of the total amount of Carbon Dioxide produced by farming crustaceans, cheese, pork, farmed fish, poultry, eggs, tofu, beans, and nuts combined.  

The graph proves how certain diets such as veganism, pescetarianism and vegetarianism help minimize the destruction of the environment by limiting the production of greenhouse gases.  These diets promote sustainable consumption and use of animals and animal products.  Veganism is the most extreme of these three diets because followers limit themselves to absolutely no consumption of animals or their byproducts.  On the graph, a vegan would only eat tofu, beans and nuts which combine to just 1.5 kilograms of greenhouse gas produced from getting 50 grams of protein from each of the three foods.  This is just 8% of the greenhouse gases produced from 50 grams of protein from beef.  If we want to decrease our negative impact on the environment a great way to start is by decreasing our consumption of beef and mammals in general.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Harrison Carter --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  Let's look at your first comparison:  "lamb and beef account for just under half of the total amount of Carbon Dioxide produced by farming crustaceans, cheese, pork, farmed fish, poultry, eggs, tofu, beans, and nuts combined."  Re-reading the title of the graph, do we know the total amount of carbon dioxide produced by food.  If not, what information would we need to make this calculation?  I think you can find it by searching online.

name: Kubair
comment info:
Title: Why we Should feel Superior:  The Over Fishing Crisis

While many have debated on the origin of these graphs, it is evident that the one on the right clearly belongs to Canada.  Not only does it include a vast amount of seafood waste, but the rest of the categories obviously do not belong to an impoverished nation or, as many have suggested, the United States.  A large county is more likely to waste more food, and while it may seem as though some impoverished nations could fit this graph, there would be far less waste present.  The US is clearly not the subject of this graph as the waste percentages are largely in the 20s and not in the 40s, 50s, or even the 60s.  Canada has had a large problem concerning over fishing in Lake Superior and consequently fits this graph perfectly.  Not only is the nation large enough to warrant wastage values in the 20s, but it also is amazing when compared to other nations' food waste management "solutions."

replies.comment info: @Kubair Thank you for your observations. Although fish is listed in the graph on the right only farmed fish (and farmed crustaceans) are listed on the left. name: Ava Sauer
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: I believe that this graph is demonstrating how detrimental our waste can be. The two highest CO2 producing industries are beef and lamb, at 17.7 kg and 9.9 kg respectively. It just so happens that meat and poultry is the third most wasted commodity, at 21% wasted. This means that of that 17.7 kg it took to make just 50 g of protein, 3.717 kg are completely wasted. This may seem minimal when you look at just one 50 g portion of beef, but when you do the math, it really adds up. In 2016, the world consumed about 129.5 billion pounds of beef, and each pound is 117g of protein. When you multiply this and divide it by 50g (to get the amount of times 17.7 kg carbon is produced), and proceed to multiply that by 17.7 kg, it gives you the final answer of total kilograms of CO2 produced because of beef worldwide, and multiplying that by .21 gives the total amount wasted. And that answer is: 1.13 trillion kg of CO2 wasted from beef every year - and that's only beef! The same steps can be replicated to calculate the mass of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere of any other source of protein, and the results will always be shocking. In all, this graph is showing, on a smaller scale, how drastic the effects of wasting certain foods are.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ava Sauer --

Thank you for researching how much beef we eat and how much protein is in a pound of beef.  Then, you walked us through the calculations for the amount of greenhouse gases produced from wasted beef.  It’s 1.13 TRILLION kg of CO2.  That seems like a lot, but could you compare this to some other amount of greenhouse gases, such as how many miles of auto or plane travel?

name: Anan Abrar
comment info:
I wonder why the graphs are side by side, as these two graphs help Americans reduce their cognitive dissonance as they make unsustainable decisions about what to eat. We're all aware that we should cut meat out of our diet for the sake of the environment. However, when I see that I'm more likely to waste fruits and vegetables, I could justify my choice to not cut out meat by saying that buying alternatives for my diet would lead to more wastage, which is environmentally bad due to deadweight loss. 

The two issues can be solved by changing the unit of the bar graph to the left. Instead of kilograms of carbon dioxide per 50 grams of protein, it should be equivalent kilograms of carbon dioxide per pound of food. Doing equivalent kilograms of carbon dioxide ensures that other emissions, such as methane, are accounted for. Just convert the damage done per gram of emitted methane to emitted gram of carbon dioxide. Listing the emissions per pound of food allows Americans to conceptualize just how harmful some of their dietary choices are for the environment. Additionally, doing quantity of food, as opposed to quantity of protein, means that Americans can also see just how efficient fruits and vegetables (in general, not niche products like beans and nuts) are to meat, so they have a harder time justifying their choices compared to the current graph.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Anan Abrar --

You raise some very thoughtful ideas about how better to display information on the amount of greenhouse gases from the food we eat and the food that we waste.  You may want to look above to the response by Ava Sauer of Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC.  She makes the calculations you suggest for beef and comes up with the total effect of the beef we eat on the environment.  If you made the comparable calculations for the other foods, you could then calculate the foods’ efficiencies, as you describe above.  THAT would be very, very interesting.  How about some more in-depth research?

Also, you suggest that eating more fruits and vegetables would result in more waste.  This would be a cause-and-effect relationship between eating them results in waste.  Do you think that this relationship exists?

name: Matthew Akuzawa
comment info: I noticed that for the average greenhouse gas impact, the average  kilograms of CO2 per 50 grams of each food seems to near Zipf's law, which states that the frequency of a data point is inversely proportional to its rank in the frequency table. While it doesn't exactly follow the law, many data points approach it. For example, first place beef has almost double the impact as second place lamb. fifth place pork is close to four fifths of fourth place cheese. This law doesn't seem to apply to the percentage of food lost. However, we can still see a similar trend in that the top few datapoints far exceed the rest of the data. I wonder whether Zipf's law, which was initially used in quantitative linguistics, can be applied to natural phenomenons. I also wonder if Zipf's law can be modified or amended in order to be more applicable. The title could be "The language of nature".

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Matthew Akuzawa --

Many participate in “What’s Going on in this Graph?” because they get to learn from each other, no matter where we are.  You refer to Zipf’s Law and I am learning from you.  I quickly read about Zipf’s Law online.  And, so now, I can think about your question “whether Zipf's law, which was initially used in quantitative linguistics, can be applied to natural phenomenon?” My first thought is that this list of foods does not include all possible foods.  There are many missing.  So, the choice is subjective, leaving out many.  If we included all foods, then the relationship would probably be different.  Would Zipf’s Law apply with the complete list?  

I hope you do more research to answer your wondering.  And, thank you for encouraging me to focus on Zipf’s law.

name: Ethan
comment info:
Protein sources such as beef, lamb, and farmed crustaceans produce the most greenhouse gasses, and they produce a lot of them. When combined, these sources produced 36.7 kilograms of CO2 per 150 grams of protein.
Fish and seafood is the food with the highest percentage wasted, nearly having ⅓ of all fish and seafood wasted. This results in a huge amount of unnecessary greenhouse gasses being pumped into our atmosphere. This unnecessary release of greenhouse gasses also occurs with all the other food sources, but in decreasing percentage.
I wonder where this data comes from and how it was acquired. I also wonder how farmed crustaceans can produce such a large amount of greenhouse gasses.
A good headline for this graph would be, “An Alarming Amount of Greenhouse Gasses, Why Food Waste Hurts the Earth.

name: Mollie Brinker
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Many Americans have an unrealistic idea that our waste just disappears when the trash people come pick it up and our food has no impact on our Earth. I saw a graph similar to this one in 2017 and it changed the way I viewed our food consumption and waste system in the United States. Environmental consciousness is important to me, so after doing some research, I decided to try to cut back on beef products. 

The graph shows the GHG emissions associated with certain foods that provide protein. Beans and nuts are at the bottom (least emissions), and beef and lamb at the top (most emissions). The graph reinforces the idea that plant based diets are more environmentally friendly than those including animal products. Within the last year, I have gradually gone completely vegan solely because of the environmental impacts of meat and animal products, as shown in the graph. 

However, I often have doubts about the true impact I’m having with the diet. Just 10-20% of green house gas emissions actually come from agriculture/animal food industry, the rest from electricity/transportation/industry sources. So, even if every person on the planet went vegan, there would still be 80-90% of the original amount of fossil fuels being added to our atmosphere. 

This graph brings up an incredibly controversial, yet important topic with many viewpoints. I’m curious to eventually read other student’s comments.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mollie Brinker  --

You’re the first response on these graphs!

You have many ideas about how what you eat affects the environment.  Is there anything in these graphs that surprises you?  Explain.  

How about sharing with us a headline that captures the main idea of these graphs?
